title: 111_hr4192
content: The "Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area Act of 2010" establishes the Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area as public lands under the Secretary of the Interior. The Act defines terms such as "public lands," "Outstanding Natural Area," "Secretary," and "Stornetta Public Lands." The Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area Act of 2010 establishes the Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area in Mendocino County, California to protect its unique values. The area will be managed by the Secretary as part of the National Landscape Conservation System. The Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area Act of 2010 establishes the Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area in Mendocino County, California to protect its unique values. The area will be managed to protect resources and allow only uses that further the purposes of the establishment, in accordance with relevant laws. The Federal lands within the area are withdrawn from various activities under public land laws, mining laws, and leasing laws. The Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area in Mendocino County, California is established to protect its unique values and will be managed to protect resources in accordance with relevant laws. Federal lands within the area are withdrawn from various activities under public land laws, mining laws, and leasing laws. The Secretary will manage the Outstanding Natural Area to conserve its unique values and allow uses that further its purposes. A management plan must be completed within 3 years to provide long-term guidance for the public lands within the area. The management plan for the Outstanding Natural Area must ensure protection of resources, propose minimal facilities, and include cultural resources management strategies in consultation with appropriate departments of the State of California. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with Federal, State, and local agencies to implement the management plan for the Outstanding Natural Area. Research activities and land acquisition adjacent to the area are also authorized. The Secretary can acquire lands adjacent to the Outstanding Natural Area through donation, exchange, or purchase. Any acquired lands will be added to the Outstanding Natural Area. Overflights, including low-level overflights, military, commercial, and general aviation, are not restricted within the area. The Secretary can acquire lands adjacent to the Outstanding Natural Area through donation, exchange, or purchase, which will be added to the area. Regulations regarding low-level overflights above the adjacent Gulf of the Farallones National Marine Sanctuary may be modified. Law enforcement activities and Native American access for traditional cultural and religious purposes are also addressed. The designation of the Outstanding Natural Area does not create buffer zones or protective perimeters. Activities outside the area that are not consistent with the purposes of the Act can still be carried out up to the boundary of the area. The closure of the area for traditional cultural and religious activities by Native American tribes should be limited to the smallest area and shortest time necessary, in accordance with the American Indian Religious Freedom Act.
